title: Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS-15)
description: Identifies possible depression in older adults aged 55 and older. The 15-item version is a brief, reliable screening tool that uses simple yes/no questions to assess depressive symptoms specific to the geriatric population over the past week

parameters.name: q1_satisfied_with_life
parameters.description: Are you basically satisfied with your life?

parameters.name: q2_dropped_activities
parameters.description: Have you dropped many of your activities and interests?

parameters.name: q3_life_empty
parameters.description: Do you feel that your life is empty?

parameters.name: q5_good_spirits
parameters.description: Are you in good spirits most of the time?

parameters.name: q6_afraid_bad_happen
parameters.description: Are you afraid that something bad is going to happen to you?

parameters.name: q7_happy_most_time
parameters.description: Do you feel happy most of the time?

parameters.name: q9_prefer_stay_home
parameters.description: Do you prefer to stay at home, rather than going out and doing new things?

parameters.name: q10_memory_problems
parameters.description: Do you feel you have more problems with memory than most?

parameters.name: q11_wonderful_to_be_alive
parameters.description: Do you think it is wonderful to be alive now?

parameters.name: q12_feel_worthless
parameters.description: Do you feel pretty worthless the way you are now?

parameters.name: q13_full_of_energy
parameters.description: Do you feel full of energy?

parameters.name: q14_situation_hopeless
parameters.description: Do you feel that your situation is hopeless?

parameters.name: q15_others_better_off
parameters.description: Do you think that most people are better off than you are?

ranges.description: Absence of clinically significant depressive symptoms
ranges.interpretation: No depression indicated. These are normal scores, depending on age, education, and complaints. Continue routine screening.
Mild depression indicated. Consider formal diagnostic evaluation. Monitor symptoms and consider counseling or supportive interventions.
Moderate depression indicated. Formal psychiatric evaluation recommended. Consider pharmacological and/or psychotherapeutic interventions.
Severe depression indicated. Urgent psychiatric evaluation required. Assess suicide risk immediately. Consider intensive treatment including medication and psychotherapy.

references: Yesavage JA, Brink TL, Rose TL, et al. Development and validation of a geriatric depression screening scale: a preliminary report. J Psychiatr Res. 1982-1983;17(1):37-49. doi: 10.1016/0022-3956(82)90033-4.
Sheikh JI, Yesavage JA. Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS): recent evidence and development of a shorter version. Clin Gerontol. 1986;5(1-2):165-173. doi: 10.1300/J018v05n01_09.

D'Ath P, Katona P, Mullan E, Evans S, Katona C. Screening, detection and management of depression in elderly primary care attenders. I: The acceptability and performance of the 15 item Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS15) and the development of short versions. Fam Pract. 1994;11(3):260-266. doi: 10.1093/fampra/11.3.260.
formula: Score = Sum of depression-indicating responses: Questions 2,3,4,6,8,9,10,12,14,15 ('Yes' = 1 point each) + Questions 1,5,7,11,13 ('No' = 1 point each)
notes: Designed specifically for adults aged 55 and older
Based on feelings over the past week
Uses simple yes/no response format suitable for elderly patients
Avoids somatic symptoms that may be confounded by medical illness
Sensitivity 81%, specificity 78% for identifying late-life depression
Scores â‰¥5 should prompt formal diagnostic evaluation
Always assess suicide risk in patients with elevated scores
Not a diagnostic tool - requires clinical evaluation for definitive diagnosis
Can be self-administered or conducted by healthcare provider
Useful for monitoring depression symptoms over time
